questions.text: In which type of cataract surgery is suturing with 10-0 nylon performed? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Extra capsular cataract surgery

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In extra capsular cataract extraction (ECCE), a larger incision (approximately 10 to 12 millimeters) is made at the limbus to remove the lens nucleus in one piece. Due to the size of this incision, suturing is necessary to close the wound properly. The suturing is typically performed using 10-0 nylon monofilament. This method can involve interrupted sutures or continuous suturing to ensure the wound is securely closed and to promote proper healing.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Phacoemulsification : This technique involves making a much smaller incision (around 3 millimeters or less) through which the lens is emulsified and aspirated. Suturing is generally not required because the small incision is self-sealing.
  • • Option A. Phacoemulsification
  • • Suturing is generally not required
  • • Option B. FLACS (Femtosecond Laser-Assisted Cataract Surgery) : This advanced technique uses a femtosecond laser to create precise incisions and to perform capsulotomy and lens fragmentation. Similar to phacoemulsification, the incisions made are small and typically do not require suturing.
  • • Option B. FLACS (Femtosecond Laser-Assisted Cataract Surgery)
  • • Option C. Manual small incision cataract surgery (SICS) : In SICS, the incision size is between 6 to 8 millimeters. Depending on the quality of the incision and tunnel, suturing may or may not be required. Good surgical technique can often avoid the need for suturing.
  • • Option C. Manual small incision cataract surgery (SICS)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Extra capsular cataract extraction (ECCE) requires suturing with 10-0 nylon due to the larger incision size necessary for removing the lens nucleus in one piece.

questions.text: A patient has had his molar teeth extracted, following which he developed loss of general sensation in the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. Which of the following nerves is likely to be injured? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Lingual nerve

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The innervation of the tongue is divided into three parts: anterior two-thirds, posterior one-third, and posterior most part.
  • • The anterior two-thirds of the tongue is derived from the first pharyngeal arch, innervated by the mandibular nerve (a branch of the trigeminal nerve ). The lingual nerve, a branch of the mandibular nerve, supplies general sensation (pain, temperature, and touch) to this part of the tongue. However, taste sensation in the anterior two-thirds is carried by the chorda tympani nerve, a branch of the facial nerve (CN VII).
  • • ). The lingual nerve, a branch of the mandibular nerve, supplies general sensation (pain, temperature, and touch) to this part of the tongue.
  • • The posterior one-third of the tongue is derived from the third pharyngeal arch and is innervated by the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX), which carries both general and taste sensation.
  • • The posterior most part of the tongue is derived from the fourth pharyngeal arch and is innervated by the vagus nerve (CN X), which carries both general and taste sensation.
  • • Tongue development:
  • • Tongue development:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Glossopharyngeal nerve: Incorrect. The glossopharyngeal nerve innervates the posterior one-third of the tongue, not the anterior two-thirds.
  • • Option A. Glossopharyngeal nerve:
  • • Option B. Hypoglossal nerve: Incorrect. The hypoglossal nerve (CN XII) provides motor innervation to the tongue muscles and does not carry sensory fibers.
  • • Option B. Hypoglossal nerve:
  • • Option C. Inferior alveolar nerve: Incorrect. The inferior alveolar nerve is a branch of the mandibular nerve that supplies the lower teeth, gingiva, and lower lip, but not the tongue.
  • • Option C. Inferior alveolar nerve:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The lingual nerve, a branch of the mandibular nerve (trigeminal nerve), supplies general sensation to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.

questions.text: What is the drug used for refraction in a child with squint? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 1% Atropine

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • 1% Atropine is the preferred drug for refraction in a child (<7 yr children) with squint, particularly because it is the strongest cycloplegic agent available.
  • • Children often have strong accommodation, which can interfere with accurate refraction, especially in cases of accommodative esotropia. Using a potent cycloplegic like 1% atropine helps to fully relax the accommodation, allowing for precise measurement of refractive errors.
  • • Atropine 1% is typically preferred in ointment form due to its longer duration of action and ease of application. The ointment can be applied to the eyelashes or lower lid, ensuring widespread coverage over the entire eye surface. This is especially useful for children under the age of 7 who require thorough cycloplegia for accurate refraction.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Tropicamide : This is a short-acting cycloplegic used primarily in adults. It is not strong enough to overcome the strong accommodation seen in children.
  • • Option B. Tropicamide
  • • Option C. Homatropine : Although it has cycloplegic properties, it is less potent than atropine and not the first choice for children with squint.
  • • Option C. Homatropine
  • • Option D. Cyclopentolate : This is another cycloplegic agent used in children, but it is less potent than atropine. It can be used if atropine is not available or in specific cases where a slightly less strong cycloplegic is sufficient.
  • • Option D. Cyclopentolate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ 1% Atropine is the drug of choice for refraction in children with squint due to its strong cycloplegic effect, ensuring accurate measurement of refractive errors by fully relaxing accommodation.
  • ➤ Mnemonic – ACHT - Order of Potency -
  • ➤ Mnemonic – ACHT
  • ➤ A tropine strongest potency C yclopentolate H omatropine T ropicamide
  • ➤ A
  • ➤ C
  • ➤ H
  • ➤ T

questions.text: A patient comes to the ER with a headache, describing it as the worst headache of his life. Initial NCCT shows SAH. What is the next step?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) CT Angiography

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The description of the "worst headache of his life" is highly suggestive of a subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH). When an initial non-contrast CT (NCCT) confirms SAH, the next step is to identify the source of bleeding, which is most commonly an aneurysm.
  • • CT Angiography is the preferred next step to localize the aneurysm and plan further management.
  • • CT Angiography
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Lumbar puncture: Indicated if the initial CT scan is negative and there is still suspicion of SAH, to check for xanthochromia.
  • • Option B. Lumbar puncture:
  • • Option C. MRI brain: Not the initial choice for acute SAH diagnosis or aneurysm localization.
  • • Option C. MRI brain:
  • • Option D. V-P shunt: Used for hydrocephalus management, not for immediate SAH diagnosis and management.
  • • Option D. V-P shunt:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a patient with confirmed subarachnoid hemorrhage on CT, the next step is CT Angiography to identify and localize the source of bleeding.

questions.text: A 15-year-old male patient presents with profuse spontaneous nasal bleeding in ENT emergency. On physical examination: Patient seems pale having Hb: 9 gm/dl. On CECT: a mass is seen which pushes septum to the contralateral side & anterior bowing of maxillary antrum is seen. All of the given statements are true regarding this mass except? (FMGE JULY 2023)

options.label: A
options.text: Most commonly seen in adolescent male

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Best treated by radiation

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The patient’s symptoms and examination findings, including profuse spontaneous nasal bleeding, pallor, and a mass pushing the septum to the contralateral side with anterior bowing of the maxillary antrum (Colman-Miller sign), are indicative of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA). This condition is most commonly seen in adolescent males, can spread to the orbit and intracranially, but it is not best treated by radiation. The primary treatment for JNA is surgical resection, not radiation therapy.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Most commonly seen in adolescent male: This is correct. JNA predominantly affects adolescent males.
  • • Option A. Most commonly seen in adolescent male:
  • • Option B. Can spread to orbit: This is correct. JNA can extend into the orbit due to its aggressive nature.
  • • Option B. Can spread to orbit:
  • • Option D. Can spread intracranially: This is correct. JNA can invade the cranial cavity, leading to significant complications.
  • • Option D. Can spread intracranially:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA) is a condition that is most commonly seen in adolescent males and primarily treated with surgical resection, not radiation.

questions.text: At the 5th postnatal day, a woman presents with sadness, irritability, restlessness, and reduced sleep. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Postpartum blues

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Postpartum blues, also known as "baby blues," typically occur within the first few days after delivery and can last up to two weeks. It is characterized by mood swings, sadness, irritability, restlessness, and difficulty sleeping. These symptoms are usually mild and self-limiting, resolving on their own with support and reassurance.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Postpartum depression : This condition occurs after the first two weeks post-delivery and can persist for months. It includes more severe symptoms such as persistent sadness, lack of interest in the baby, feelings of hopelessness, and possibly suicidal thoughts.
  • • Option B. Postpartum depression
  • • more severe symptoms
  • • Option C. Postpartum anxiety : This condition involves excessive worry, anxiety, and often includes physical symptoms like palpitations or hyperventilation . It can occur at any time during the postpartum period.
  • • Option C. Postpartum anxiety
  • • palpitations or hyperventilation
  • • Option D. Postpartum psychosis : This is a rare but severe condition that usually occurs within the first few weeks after delivery. It involves symptoms such as hallucinations, delusions, severe agitation, and risk of harm to the mother or baby.
  • • Option D. Postpartum psychosis
  • • severe condition

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Postpartum blues are common in the first few days after delivery and are characterized by sadness, irritability, restlessness, and reduced sleep. The condition is generally mild and self-limiting, resolving with support and care.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs undergoes Hofmann’s degradation? FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cisatracurium

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Cisatracurium undergoes Hofmann elimination, which is a temperature and pH-dependent process that does not require enzymatic activity for metabolism. This makes it particularly useful for patients with certain types of organ dysfunction.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Mivacurium: It is a short-acting neuromuscular blocking agent that is primarily broken down by plasma cholinesterase and does not significantly undergo Hofmann elimination.
  • • Option B. Mivacurium:
  • • Option C. Pancuronium: This is a long-acting neuromuscular blocking agent that is primarily metabolized by the liver and excreted by the kidneys, and it does not undergo Hofmann elimination.
  • • Option C. Pancuronium:
  • • Option D. Vecuronium: Like pancuronium, it is also metabolized by the liver and excreted by the kidneys and does not undergo Hofmann degradation.
  • • Option D. Vecuronium:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cisatracurium is unique among the non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agents for undergoing Hofmann elimination, a process that allows safe use in patients with hepatic and renal insufficiency.

questions.text: A 36-year-old male patient presents in ENT OPD with complaints of hearing trouble from the left side of the ear for the last 2 months. The doctor performs pure tone audiometry shown below. Interpret the audiogram? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Left sided conductive deafness

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The pure tone audiometry (PTA) shows results for the left ear, indicated by the blue color. The audiogram demonstrates a significant air-bone gap, which is characteristic of conductive hearing loss. In conductive hearing loss, the air conduction thresholds are worse (higher dB levels) than the bone conduction thresholds, but the bone conduction remains within normal limits. This wide air-bone gap confirms the diagnosis of left-sided conductive deafness.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Left side sensorineural deafness: Sensorineural hearing loss would present with both air and bone conduction thresholds being equally impaired, without a significant air-bone gap. This is not the case here.
  • • Option B. Left side sensorineural deafness:
  • • Option C. Right sided conductive deafness: The audiogram is for the left ear (indicated by blue color), not the right ear. Hence, this option is incorrect.
  • • Option C. Right sided conductive deafness:
  • • Option D. Right sided sensorineural deafness: Similarly, this option is incorrect as the audiogram provided is for the left ear, and it shows conductive, not sensorineural, hearing loss.
  • • Option D. Right sided sensorineural deafness:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Conductive hearing loss is indicated by a significant air-bone gap on pure tone audiometry, with air conduction thresholds being worse than bone conduction thresholds, as seen in this left-sided case

questions.text: In a class of 25 students, the student with the highest weight (= 39 kg) was wrongly recorded as 93 kg. What will happen to central tendency now? (FMGE JULY 2023)

  • ➤ Note - Measures of Central Tendency –
  • ➤ Note - Measures of Central Tendency –
  • ➤ 1. Mean (Average): Is obtained as sum of all values divided by the no. of values.
  • ➤ Mean = S x/n
  • ➤ 2. Median: Middle-most value in a distribution arranged in an ascending or descending order of values.
  • ➤ Median = ((n + 1)/2)th value in ascending order
  • ➤ 3. Mode: Most frequent or most commonly occurring value in a distribution

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presented with acute onset left-sided hemiparesis. The symptoms started 3 hours ago. On examination, BP is 200/100 mm Hg. CT head is shown below. Which of the following should not be done in this patient? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Immediate thrombolysis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The patient has presented with acute onset left-sided hemiparesis, and the CT scan shows evidence of intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH), indicating a hemorrhagic stroke. In the case of hemorrhagic stroke, immediate thrombolysis is contraindicated as it can worsen the bleeding. Thrombolytic agents, such as tissue plasminogen activator (tPA), are used to dissolve clots in ischemic strokes but can be harmful in hemorrhagic strokes.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Blood pressure control: Managing high blood pressure is crucial in patients with hemorrhagic stroke to prevent further bleeding.
  • • Option A. Blood pressure control:
  • • Option C. Clotting factor administration: In cases of hemorrhagic stroke, administering clotting factors or other agents to help control bleeding may be necessary.
  • • Option C. Clotting factor administration:
  • • Option D. Edema management: Managing cerebral edema is essential to reduce intracranial pressure and prevent further complications in hemorrhagic stroke patients.
  • • Option D. Edema management:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Immediate thrombolysis should never be administered in patients with hemorrhagic stroke, as it can exacerbate the bleeding and worsen the patient's condition.

questions.text: A person consumed 2 bottles of alcohol purchased from a local shop and presented to the emergency department with blurring of vision, nausea, confusion, and hypotension. What should be given for the treatment? (FMGE 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ethyl alcohol

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Blurring of vision, along with other symptoms such as nausea, confusion, and hypotension, suggests methyl alcohol (methanol) poisoning. Methyl alcohol is toxic because its metabolism produces formic acid, which is particularly harmful to the eyes and can cause blindness.
  • • Key points to understand about methyl alcohol poisoning and its treatment:
  • • Key points to understand about methyl alcohol poisoning and its treatment:
  • • Methyl Alcohol (Methanol) Poisoning: Methanol is often used to adulterate ethyl alcohol (ethanol) in locally produced alcoholic beverages because it is cheaper and has similar initial effects. Methanol metabolism produces formic acid, which is toxic, particularly to the eyes, causing symptoms like blurring of vision. Treatment of Methanol Poisoning: Ethyl Alcohol (Ethanol): Ethanol is used as an antidote for methanol poisoning because it competes with methanol for alcohol dehydrogenase, the enzyme responsible for metabolizing both alcohols. By competing for this enzyme, ethanol prevents the formation of toxic metabolites from methanol. Fomepizole (4-Methylpyrazole): Another antidote that inhibits alcohol dehydrogenase and prevents the formation of toxic metabolites. Sodium Bicarbonate: Used to correct metabolic acidosis. Dialysis: Used in severe cases to remove methanol and formic acid from the blood.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents with a fever. He is an intravenous drug user. On examination, a temperature of 38.5°C, and some spots can be noted over the fundus. CBC showed a leukocyte count of 20,000/cu mm. Blood has been sent for culture. Infective Endocarditis is suspected. How many minor Duke's Criteria are satisfied for the diagnosis? ( FMGE July 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 3

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Duke's Criteria for the diagnosis of infective endocarditis include both major and minor criteria. In this case, the minor criteria that are satisfied include:
  • • Fever > 38°C: The patient has a fever of 38.5°C. Predisposing heart condition or intravenous drug use: The patient is an intravenous drug user. Immunologic phenomena: The presence of spots over the fundus suggests Roth spots, which are a form of immunologic phenomenon.
  • • Fever > 38°C: The patient has a fever of 38.5°C.
  • • Fever > 38°C:
  • • Predisposing heart condition or intravenous drug use: The patient is an intravenous drug user.
  • • Predisposing heart condition or intravenous drug use:
  • • Immunologic phenomena: The presence of spots over the fundus suggests Roth spots, which are a form of immunologic phenomenon.
  • • Immunologic phenomena:
  • • The other minor criteria –
  • • Vascular phenomena Blood culture is positive, but not meeting major criteria.
  • • Vascular phenomena
  • • Blood culture is positive, but not meeting major criteria.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. 1: Only fever would be counted.
  • • Option A. 1:
  • • Option B. 2: Fever and IV drug use would be counted.
  • • Option B. 2:
  • • Option D. 4: This would require additional minor criteria that are not mentioned in the question.
  • • Option D. 4:
  • • Additional Information -
  • • Additional Information -
  • • Duke’s Major criteria for IE –
  • • Duke’s Major criteria for IE –
  • • Blood culture persistently positive for typical microorganism ( ≥3 blood culture) from different puncture sides and gap between first and last culture should be atleast 1 hour: for diagnosis 2 out of 3 culture should be positive and for the same organism. Except Q fever -Coxiella Brunetti only single culture is enough. Imaging – Positive Echocardiogram – For IE specifically Transesophageal Echo – will show vegetation near the valves
  • • Blood culture persistently positive for typical microorganism ( ≥3 blood culture) from different puncture sides and gap between first and last culture should be atleast 1 hour: for diagnosis 2 out of 3 culture should be positive and for the same organism. Except Q fever -Coxiella Brunetti only single culture is enough.
  • • Imaging – Positive Echocardiogram – For IE specifically Transesophageal Echo – will show vegetation near the valves

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In this case, three minor Duke's criteria are satisfied for the diagnosis of infective endocarditis: fever > 38°C, intravenous drug use, and immunologic phenomena (Roth spots).

questions.text: Which is NOT used as an emergency contraceptive? (FMGE JULY 2023)

  • • Option C.
  • • Combined Oral Contraceptive Pills (OCPs)
  • • Option D. LNG (Levonorgestrel) 1.5 mg single tablet : This is commonly available and should be taken within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse. It is highly effective when used promptly and is available under various brand names like I-Pill or E-Pill. (95-97% effective)
  • • Option D. LNG (Levonorgestrel) 1.5 mg single tablet
  • • Note – The overall most effective emergency contraceptive is – IUCD – used with in 5 days of unprotected Intercourse
  • • Note – The overall most effective emergency contraceptive is – IUCD – used with in 5 days of unprotected Intercourse

questions.text: Which of the following factors is not included in ABCD2 scoring? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) History of stroke

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The ABCD2 score is used to assess the risk of developing a subsequent stroke following a transient ischemic attack (TIA).
  • • The components of the ABCD2 score include:
  • • A (Age): Age 60 years or older scores 1 point. B (Blood Pressure): Systolic blood pressure of 140 mm Hg or higher, or diastolic blood pressure of 90 mm Hg or higher scores 1 point. C (Clinical Features): Unilateral weakness scores 2 points; speech disturbance without weakness scores 1 point. D (Diabetes): Presence of diabetes scores 1 point. D (Duration of Symptoms): Symptoms lasting 60 minutes or longer score 2 points; symptoms lasting 10-59 minutes score 1 point.
  • • A (Age): Age 60 years or older scores 1 point.
  • • A (Age):
  • • B (Blood Pressure): Systolic blood pressure of 140 mm Hg or higher, or diastolic blood pressure of 90 mm Hg or higher scores 1 point.
  • • B (Blood Pressure):
  • • C (Clinical Features): Unilateral weakness scores 2 points; speech disturbance without weakness scores 1 point.
  • • C (Clinical Features):
  • • D (Diabetes): Presence of diabetes scores 1 point.
  • • D (Diabetes):
  • • D (Duration of Symptoms): Symptoms lasting 60 minutes or longer score 2 points; symptoms lasting 10-59 minutes score 1 point.
  • • D (Duration of Symptoms):
  • • History of stroke is not included in the ABCD2 scoring system. Instead, it is a component of other scoring systems, such as the CHADS2 or CHA2DS2-VASc scores, which are used to assess the risk of stroke in patients with atrial fibrillation and to guide anticoagulation therapy.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Age: Age 60 years or older is a factor in the ABCD2 score and scores 1 point.
  • • Option A. Age:
  • • Option B. Hypertension: Elevated blood pressure is included in the ABCD2 score and scores 1 point.
  • • Option B. Hypertension:
  • • Option C. Diabetes mellitus: The presence of diabetes is included in the ABCD2 score and scores 1 point.
  • • Option C. Diabetes mellitus:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The ABCD2 score includes age, blood pressure, clinical features, duration of symptoms, and diabetes. History of stroke is not included in this scoring system but is part of other risk assessment tools like CHADS2 and CHA2DS2-VASc

questions.text: Which of the following forms the lateral boundary of the femoral triangle? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Medial margin of sartorius

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The femoral triangle is a triangular muscular depression located in the upper part of the thigh. Its boundaries are formed by the inguinal ligament (base), the medial margin of the sartorius muscle (lateral boundary), and the medial border of the adductor longus muscle (medial boundary). The apex of the triangle is formed by the intersection of the sartorius and adductor longus muscles.
  • • The sartorius muscle, the longest muscle in the body, originates from the anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS) and forms the lateral boundary of the femoral triangle with its medial margin. The adductor longus muscle, originating from the pubic tubercle area, forms the medial boundary of the triangle.
  • • The floor of the femoral triangle is formed by the adductor longus, pectineus, psoas major tendon, and iliacus muscle (Mnemonic "APPI"). The roof of the triangle is formed by the skin, superficial fascia, and deep fascia.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Lateral margin of adductor longus: Incorrect. The adductor longus muscle forms the medial boundary of the femoral triangle, not the lateral boundary.
  • • Option A. Lateral margin of adductor longus:
  • • Option B. Medial margin of adductor longus: Incorrect. The medial margin of the adductor longus muscle forms the medial boundary of the femoral triangle, not the lateral boundary.
  • • Option B. Medial margin of adductor longus:
  • • Option C. Lateral margin of sartorius: Incorrect. The sartorius muscle forms the lateral boundary of the femoral triangle, but it is the medial margin of the sartorius that specifically forms this boundary.
  • • Option C. Lateral margin of sartorius:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The medial margin of the sartorius muscle forms the lateral boundary of the femoral triangle, while the medial border of the adductor longus muscle forms the medial boundary.

questions.text: A patient sustained an injury to the head and now presents with blood collected around his eyes. Attachment of which of the following structures leads to this condition? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Loose areolar layer

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The condition, where blood collects around the eyes following a head injury, is known as " raccoon eyes" or "black eyes".
  • • raccoon eyes" or "black eyes".
  • • Layers of the scalp -
  • • Layers of the scalp -
  • • The scalp consists of five layers, which can be remembered using the mnemonic "SCALP":
  • • mnemonic "SCALP":
  • • Skin Connective tissue (superficial fascia) Aponeurotic layer (epicranial aponeurosis) Loose areolar layer Periosteum (pericranium)
  • • Skin
  • • Connective tissue (superficial fascia)
  • • Aponeurotic layer (epicranial aponeurosis)
  • • Loose areolar layer
  • • Periosteum (pericranium)
  • • Among these layers, the loose areolar layer (4th layer) is the key to understanding the development of raccoon eyes. This layer lacks bony attachments anteriorly and is continuous with the eyelids. When a head injury occurs, the emissary veins or other vessels in this layer may rupture, causing blood to accumulate. Since the loose areolar layer is continuous with the eyelids, the blood can easily spread and collect around the eyes, resulting in the characteristic black eye appearance.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Superficial fascia: Incorrect. Although the superficial fascia is one of the layers of the scalp, it is not the layer responsible for the continuity with the eyelids and the development of raccoon eyes.
  • • Option A. Superficial fascia:
  • • Option C. Periosteum: Incorrect. The periosteum, also known as the pericranium, is the innermost layer of the scalp, firmly attached to the underlying bone. It does not have continuity with the eyelids and is not the cause of raccoon eyes.
  • • Option C. Periosteum:
  • • Option D. Pericranium: Incorrect. The pericranium is another name for the periosteum, the innermost layer of the scalp. It is not responsible for the development of raccoon eyes.
  • • Option D. Pericranium:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The loose areolar layer of the scalp, which lacks bony attachments anteriorly and is continuous with the eyelids, is responsible for the development of raccoon eyes following a head injury due to the accumulation and spread of blood from ruptured vessels.

questions.text: In which condition is pupillary light reaction absent and accommodation reaction present? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Neurosyphilis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The condition described is characteristic of the Argyll Robertson pupil, which is associated with neurosyphilis. In this condition, the pupillary light reflex is absent, meaning the pupils do not constrict in response to light. However, the accommodation reflex, which involves pupil constriction when focusing on a near object, is preserved. This phenomenon is often summarized by the -
  • • Argyll Robertson pupil,
  • • neurosyphilis.
  • • Mnemonic "ARP and PRA" (Accommodation Reflex Present and Pupillary Reflex Absent).
  • • Mnemonic "ARP and PRA" (Accommodation Reflex Present and Pupillary Reflex Absent).
  • • The underlying mechanism involves damage to the interneurons in the pretectal area of the midbrain, which affects the light reflex pathway while sparing the accommodation pathway.
  • • The Near triad , consisting of accommodation, convergence, and miosis, remains intact in neurosyphilis, explaining why accommodation is preserved.
  • • Near triad
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Horner’s syndrome : This condition is characterized by ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis due to a disruption in the sympathetic pathways. The pupillary light reaction is not typically absent.
  • • Option B. Horner’s syndrome
  • • ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis
  • • Option C. Papilledema : This condition involves swelling of the optic disc due to increased intracranial pressure. The pupillary light reaction is usually normal in papilledema.
  • • Option C. Papilledema
  • • swelling of the optic disc
  • • Option D. Optic neuritis : This inflammation of the optic nerve often leads to a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) or Marcus Gunn pupil, where the affected eye shows a reduced direct response to light. However, the accommodation reaction is not selectively preserved as described.
  • • Option D. Optic neuritis
  • • relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) or Marcus Gunn pupil,

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Argyll Robertson pupil, associated with neurosyphilis, presents with absent pupillary light reaction and preserved accommodation reaction, highlighting a distinctive neuro-ophthalmologic sign of this condition.

questions.text: A patient presents with seizures. His CT head reveals multiple parenchymal cysts. Which of the following is not a part of immediate management in the next 24 hours? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Antiparasitic drugs

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Antiparasitic drugs , such as albendazole or praziquantel , are not part of the immediate management. Starting antiparasitic treatment without adequate anti-inflammatory coverage (steroids) can worsen the patient's condition by increasing inflammation due to the destruction of the cysts.
  • • Antiparasitic drugs
  • • albendazole or praziquantel
  • • Antiparasitic therapy ( albendazole or praziquantel or both ) can be initiated later, typically along with steroids, to mitigate this risk.
  • • albendazole or praziquantel or both
  • • Doses –
  • • Albendazole – 15 mg/Kg/day (Max. of 1200 mg/day) Praziquantel – 50-100 mg/kg/day in 3 divided doses
  • • Albendazole – 15 mg/Kg/day (Max. of 1200 mg/day)
  • • Praziquantel – 50-100 mg/kg/day in 3 divided doses
  • • Note – Severe disease or >2 cyst – Combination of both drug in doses of 15 mg/kg/day Albendazole + 50mg/kg/day Praziquantel
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • In a case of neurocysticercosis, the immediate management of a patient presenting with seizures and multiple parenchymal cysts on CT includes:
  • • Option B. Steroids: To reduce inflammation and surrounding edema caused by the cysts.
  • • Option B. Steroids:
  • • Option C. Antiepileptics: To control seizures, which are the most common presentation of neurocysticercosis.
  • • Option C. Antiepileptics:
  • • Option D. Anti-edema treatment: To manage any cerebral edema and prevent further complications.
  • • Option D. Anti-edema treatment:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the immediate management of neurocysticercosis presenting with seizures, antiepileptics, steroids, and anti-edema treatment are essential, while antiparasitic drugs can be started later.

questions.text: A child as shown below presented to the ENT department with the following finding. She gives complaint of recurrent bony fractures along with reduced hearing. On further investigation, Tympanometry showed the following finding. What would you name this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Van der Hoeve syndrome

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The child presents with recurrent bony fractures and reduced hearing, which are indicative of osteogenesis imperfecta (imperfectly developed bones).
  • • The tympanometry shows an AS type of curve, suggesting otosclerosis.
  • • Additionally, the child has a blue sclera, which is a characteristic feature of osteogenesis imperfecta.
  • • This combination of symptoms — osteogenesis imperfecta, blue sclera, and otosclerosis — forms a triad known as Van der Hoeve syndrome.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Waardenburg syndrome: Waardenburg syndrome is characterized by congenital sensorineural hearing loss and pigmentary abnormalities such as a white forelock of hair (piebaldism).
  • • Option A. Waardenburg syndrome:
  • • Option C. Usher's syndrome: Usher's syndrome is associated with retinitis pigmentosa and congenital sensorineural hearing loss.
  • • Option C. Usher's syndrome:
  • • Retinitis pigmentosa
  • • Option D. Pendred syndrome: Pendred syndrome includes congenital sensorineural hearing loss and goiter.
  • • Option D. Pendred syndrome:

questions.text: A 5-month-old baby was brought to the ENT OPD with complaints of abnormal noise during breathing, the severity of which increases during crying. On examination, inspiratory stridors are heard and on laryngoscopy, the following finding is seen. The diagnosis would be? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Laryngomalacia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The baby presents with abnormal noise during breathing that worsens with crying, and inspiratory stridor, indicating an upper airway issue. The laryngoscopy image shows an omega-shaped epiglottis, which is characteristic of laryngomalacia. Laryngomalacia is the most common cause of stridor in infants and results from the collapse of the supraglottic structures during inspiration.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Congenital laryngeal web: A congenital laryngeal web would present with a hoarse cry and respiratory distress due to the fusion of the vocal cords. The airway would be significantly compromised, as shown below.
  • • Option B. Congenital laryngeal web:
  • • Option C. Congenital subglottic stenosis: Subglottic stenosis would show a narrowed subglottic area below the vocal cords, which is not consistent with the omega-shaped epiglottis seen in the image.
  • • Option C. Congenital subglottic stenosis:
  • • Option D. Congenital bilateral choanal atresia: Choanal atresia involves the blockage of the nasal passages and presents with difficulty breathing, particularly while feeding, but does not typically present with the findings of an omega-shaped epiglottis or inspiratory stridor.
  • • Option D. Congenital bilateral choanal atresia:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Laryngomalacia is characterized by inspiratory stridor that worsens with crying and is identified by the presence of an omega-shaped epiglottis on laryngoscopy. It is the most common cause of stridor in infants.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presented with back pain for the past 3 months. On examination, he has pallor, and gamma globulins are elevated. LFT is normal. X-ray spine shows multiple lytic lesions. Which of the following cells are involved in the pathogenesis of this patient's condition?

Elevated gamma globulins: Suggests a monoclonal protein spike (M spike) on serum protein electrophoresis. Multiple lytic lesions on X-ray: Classic radiographic finding in multiple myeloma due to bone destruction.
  • • Back pain: Common in multiple myeloma due to bone involvement.
  • • Back pain:
  • • Pallor: Indicates anemia, a common finding in multiple myeloma.
  • • Pallor:
  • • Elevated gamma globulins: Suggests a monoclonal protein spike (M spike) on serum protein electrophoresis.
  • • Elevated gamma globulins:
  • • Multiple lytic lesions on X-ray: Classic radiographic finding in multiple myeloma due to bone destruction.
  • • Multiple lytic lesions on X-ray:
  • • In multiple myeloma, malignant clonal plasma cells proliferate in the bone marrow, leading to the production of abnormal monoclonal immunoglobulins, bone destruction, and marrow infiltration.
  • • plasma cells
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A, B & D: Not primarily involved in multiple myeloma.
  • • Option A, B & D:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Multiple myeloma is a plasma cell neoplasm characterized by anemia, elevated gamma globulins, and lytic bone lesions, with plasma cells being the key pathological cells involved.

questions.text: Which of the following layers is absent in the esophagus? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The esophagus is a tubular structure located in the thoracic cavity, connecting the pharynx to the stomach. Unlike most of the gastrointestinal tract, the esophagus lacks a serosa layer. The serosa is a thin membrane derived from the peritoneum, which is a structure found in the abdominal cavity. Since the esophagus is primarily located in the thoracic cavity, it does not have a serosa layer covering its external surface.
  • • However, it is important to note that the short, intra-abdominal portion of the esophagus (just before it connects to the stomach) is covered by a serosa layer derived from the peritoneum. This portion is an exception to the general rule that the esophagus lacks a serosa.
  • • The esophageal wall is composed of the following layers from the lumen outwards:
  • • The esophageal wall is composed of the following layers from the lumen outwards:
  • • Mucosa: The innermost layer, consisting of epithelium, lamina propria, and muscularis mucosae. Submucosa: A layer of connective tissue containing blood vessels, lymphatics, and esophageal glands. Muscularis externa (or muscularis propria): Consists of an inner circular layer and an outer longitudinal layer of smooth muscle. Adventitia: The outermost layer of the esophagus, composed of loose connective tissue. This layer is not called serosa because it is not derived from the peritoneum.
  • • Mucosa: The innermost layer, consisting of epithelium, lamina propria, and muscularis mucosae.
  • • Mucosa:
  • • Submucosa: A layer of connective tissue containing blood vessels, lymphatics, and esophageal glands.
  • • Submucosa:
  • • Muscularis externa (or muscularis propria): Consists of an inner circular layer and an outer longitudinal layer of smooth muscle.
  • • Muscularis externa (or muscularis propria):
  • • Adventitia: The outermost layer of the esophagus, composed of loose connective tissue. This layer is not called serosa because it is not derived from the peritoneum.
  • • Adventitia:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Mucosa: Incorrect. The mucosa is present in the esophagus and forms the innermost layer.
  • • Option A. Mucosa:
  • • Option B. Submucosa: Incorrect. The submucosa is present in the esophagus and lies between the mucosa and muscularis externa.
  • • Option B. Submucosa:
  • • Option C. Muscularis externa: Incorrect. The muscularis externa is present in the esophagus and consists of two layers of smooth muscle.
  • • Option C. Muscularis externa:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The esophagus lacks a serosa layer because it is primarily located in the thoracic cavity, except for the short intra-abdominal portion just before it connects to the stomach.

questions.text: Which of the following is a direct cause of maternal death? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Pre-eclampsia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Maternal deaths can be classified into direct and indirect causes. Direct causes are those that result from complications of pregnancy, labor, or the postpartum period, whereas indirect causes are conditions that are exacerbated by pregnancy.
  • • Pre-eclampsia : This is a direct cause of maternal death. Pre-eclampsia is a hypertensive disorder of pregnancy that can lead to severe complications such as eclampsia, HELLP syndrome, stroke, and organ failure, all of which can directly result in maternal mortality.
  • • Pre-eclampsia
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Anemia : This is considered an indirect cause of maternal death. While severe anemia can exacerbate complications during pregnancy and childbirth, it is not a direct cause but increases the risk of infections, hemorrhage, and other complications.
  • • Option A. Anemia
  • • indirect cause
  • • Option B. Heart disease : This is also an indirect cause of maternal death. Pre-existing heart disease can worsen during pregnancy due to the increased cardiovascular demands, but it is not a complication arising directly from pregnancy.
  • • Option B. Heart disease
  • • indirect cause
  • • Option C. Embolism : Pulmonary embolism is considered an indirect cause of maternal death when it occurs due to pregnancy-related factors like deep vein thrombosis.
  • • Option C. Embolism

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pre-eclampsia is a direct cause of maternal death, directly associated with complications arising from pregnancy, labor, or the postpartum period.

questions.text: Which of the following samples is considered the best for detecting lead poisoning? (FMGE 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Blood

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Lead poisoning primarily affects the synthesis of heme by inhibiting three crucial enzymes: Aminolevulinic acid dehydratase (ALAD), Coproporphyrinogen oxidase, and Ferrochelatase . This inhibition leads to the accumulation of their immediate precursors: aminolevulinic acid, coproporphyrinogen, and protoporphyrin.
  • • Aminolevulinic acid dehydratase (ALAD), Coproporphyrinogen oxidase, and Ferrochelatase
  • • Due to this, lead poisoning can present with various symptoms, including anemia, punctate basophilia (bluish granules in RBCs), and elevated levels of these precursors. The most reliable diagnostic measure for lead poisoning is the blood lead level (> 70 μg/dl), which correlates best with adverse clinical symptoms and the toxicity profile of lead.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Hair : While lead can be detected in hair, it does not correlate as well with the severity of poisoning or clinical symptoms as blood levels do.
  • • Option A. Hair
  • • Option C. Saliva : Saliva is not a standard sample for lead detection and does not provide reliable results.
  • • Option C. Saliva
  • • Option D. Urine : Though urine can show lead excretion, it is not as reliable as blood levels for correlating with toxicity and clinical manifestations.
  • • Option D. Urine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Blood lead levels are the most reliable and best indicator for detecting lead poisoning, correlating well with clinical symptoms and toxicity.
  • ➤ Laboratory diagnosis of Lead Poisoning –
  • ➤ Laboratory diagnosis of Lead Poisoning –
  • ➤ Porphyrinuria due to coproporphyrin III. Blood lead level > 70–100 μg/dl. Protoporphyrin > 35 μg/dl. Urine lead level > 0.15–0.3 mg/l.
  • ➤ Porphyrinuria due to coproporphyrin III.
  • ➤ Blood lead level > 70–100 μg/dl.
  • ➤ Protoporphyrin > 35 μg/dl.
  • ➤ Urine lead level > 0.15–0.3 mg/l.

questions.text: A female weighing 40 kg has a serum sodium level of 120 mEq/L. Calculate the sodium deficit for a desired sodium concentration of 140 mEq/L:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 400 mEq

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The sodium deficit can be calculated using the formula:
  • • Sodium Deficit=Total Body Water×(Desired Sodium−Actual Sodium)
  • • For females, the Total Body Water (TBW) is 50% of body weight
  • • TBW=0.5×Body Weight
  • • Here, the body weight is 40 kg:
  • • TBW=0.5×40 kg=20 LTBW=0.5×40 kg=20 L
  • • The desired sodium concentration is 140 mEq/L and the actual sodium concentration is 120
  • • mEq/L:
  • • Sodium Deficit=20 L×(140 mEq/L−120 mEq/L) =400 mEq
  • • Therefore, the sodium deficit is 400 mEq.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objectives
  • ➤ The sodium deficit for a female weighing 40 kg with a serum sodium level of 120 mEq/L, aiming for a desired sodium concentration of 140 mEq/L, is 400 mEq.

questions.text: A patient presents with nasal obstruction after being hit on the face from the front. On examination, a boggy swelling of the septum is seen on both sides (see picture below), which is fluctuant on palpation with a swab or blunt probe. He should be managed by?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Incision & Drainage

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The patient presents with nasal obstruction and a boggy, fluctuant swelling of the septum on both sides after trauma, which indicates a septal hematoma. A septal hematoma is a collection of blood within the septal tissues and requires immediate drainage to prevent complications such as infection, abscess formation, or septal cartilage necrosis. The definitive treatment is incision and drainage to evacuate the collected blood.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Nasal packing: Nasal packing is not the treatment of choice for a septal hematoma. It is typically used for controlling nasal bleeding (epistaxis).
  • • Option B. Nasal packing:
  • • Option C. Antibiotics: While antibiotics may be used to prevent secondary infection, they do not address the primary issue of the hematoma and are not the definitive treatment.
  • • Option C. Antibiotics:
  • • Option D. Nasal decongestants: Nasal decongestants are used to reduce nasal mucosal swelling and congestion but are not effective in treating a septal hematoma.
  • • Option D. Nasal decongestants:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A septal hematoma, characterized by a boggy, fluctuant swelling of the septum after nasal trauma, should be treated with immediate incision and drainage to prevent complications and ensure proper healing.

Anal fixation is also believed to potentially lead to obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) based on this theory.

questions.text: A maid in the house presented in the clinic with complaint of pain & swelling at the knee. Which bursa is involved in this condition? (FMGE JULY 2023)

  • • The prepatellar bursa is located in front of the patella (kneecap). The term "housemaid's knee" is commonly used to describe prepatellar bursitis, which is inflammation of the prepatellar bursa. This condition is typically caused by repetitive kneeling, which is common in individuals who perform frequent cleaning or other activities that require prolonged kneeling.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. A: This indicates the suprapatellar bursa, located above the patella. It is not typically associated with "housemaid's knee."
  • • Option A. A:
  • • Option C. C: This indicates the subcutaneous infrapatellar bursa, located below the patella, which is associated with "clergyman's knee" due to repeated kneeling in a kneeling position.
  • • Option C. C:
  • • Option D. D: This indicates the deep infrapatellar bursa, also located below the patella, but deeper and not typically involved in "housemaid's knee."
  • • Option D. D:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The prepatellar bursa, located in front of the patella, is the bursa involved in "housemaid's knee" (prepatellar bursitis).

questions.text: A neonate on breast feeding develops jaundice. Urine Benedict’s test is positive. The enzyme deficiency is_________: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Galactose-1-P Uridyl Transferase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The neonate's symptoms, including jaundice and a positive Benedict's test for reducing sugars in the urine, are indicative of galactosemia. In galactosemia, there is a deficiency of the enzyme galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase, which is involved in the conversion of galactose-1-phosphate to glucose-1-phosphate. Gal-1-P accumulates causes product inhibition of galactokinase resulting in galactose accumulation which comes out in urine giving positive Benedict’s test.
  • ➤ Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 198
  • ➤ Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 198

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy will have ____ permanent and ____ temporary teeth?(FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 20, 4

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Mixed dentition is a period when both temporary (primary) and permanent teeth are present in the oral cavity. This phase typically occurs between the ages of 6 to 11 years.
  • • Key points to remember about mixed dentition:
  • • Key points to remember about mixed dentition:
  • • 1. Age Range: The mixed dentition period spans from 6 to 11 years.
  • • 1. Age Range:
  • • 2. Total Number of Teeth: During mixed dentition, the total number of teeth (temporary plus permanent) is consistently 24.
  • • 2. Total Number of Teeth:
  • • 3. Calculation of Permanent Teeth: The number of permanent teeth can be calculated using the formula:
  • • 3. Calculation of Permanent Teeth:
  • • Permanent Teeth=(Age−5)×4
  • • For a 10-year-old child:
  • • Permanent Teeth=(10−5)×4=20
  • • Hence, the number of permanent teeth is 20.
  • • 4. Calculation of Temporary Teeth: The number of temporary teeth can be determined by subtracting the number of permanent teeth from the total number of teeth:
  • • 4. Calculation of Temporary Teeth:
  • • Temporary Teeth=24−Permanent Teeth
  • • Therefore:
  • • Temporary Teeth=24−20=4
  • • Thus, a 10-year-old boy will have 20 permanent teeth and 4 temporary teeth.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ During the mixed dentition period (6-11 years), a 10-year-old typically has 20 permanent teeth and 4 temporary teeth. Use the formula (Age−5)×4 to determine the number of permanent teeth.
  • ➤ Number if teeth with age -
  • ➤ Number if teeth with age -

questions.text: A 39-year-old patient presents to the OPD with the complaint of pain over his ear. He also complains of difficulty in eating food and the inability to close his eyes completely. On examination, there is a swelling below his ear. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be involved in this condition? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Facial nerve

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The patient's symptoms, including ear pain, difficulty eating, and inability to close the eye completely, strongly suggest a case of facial palsy or Bell's palsy. Bell's palsy is a condition characterized by sudden weakness or paralysis of the facial muscles, typically affecting one side of the face. The facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) is responsible for controlling the muscles of facial expression, and its dysfunction leads to the presented symptoms.
  • • The presence of a swelling below the ear further supports the involvement of the facial nerve. The parotid gland, located in this region, is closely associated with the facial nerve, which divides into five terminal branches within the gland. Damage or inflammation of the parotid gland can lead to compression or involvement of the facial nerve, resulting in facial palsy.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Great auricular nerve: Incorrect. While the great auricular nerve provides sensory innervation over the angle of the mandible and the area around the ear (shaving area), it is not directly responsible for the motor functions affected in this case. If the patient had ear pain or loss of sensation in the shaving area without the Bell's palsy features, the great auricular nerve could have been considered.
  • • Option A. Great auricular nerve:
  • • Option C. Vagus nerve: Incorrect. The vagus nerve (cranial nerve X) does not directly control the facial muscles or cause the symptoms described here.
  • • Option C. Vagus nerve:
  • • Option D. Auriculotemporal nerve: Incorrect. The auriculotemporal nerve, a branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve, supplies sensory innervation to the auricle and temporal region but does not control the facial muscles or cause the symptoms of facial palsy. If the patient had symptoms like increased sweating, redness, or blood supply in this area, it could have suggested an auriculotemporal nerve syndrome (Frey's syndrome).
  • • Option D. Auriculotemporal nerve:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) is responsible for controlling the muscles of facial expression, and its dysfunction can lead to facial palsy or Bell's palsy, characterized by weakness or paralysis of the facial muscles, difficulty eating, and inability to close the eye completely.

questions.text: A patient has microcytic hypochromic anemia and was observed to have delayed wound healing after a minor surgery. He gives history of gum bleeding also. He is most likely to have deficiency of: (FMGE JANUARY 2023)

Deficiency leads to scurvy, which manifests with symptoms like gum bleeding, poor wound healing, and anemia. The anemia is typically normocytic but can be microcytic due to associated blood loss and iron deficiency.

questions.text: A patient presents with a pansystolic murmur and features of carditis. Echocardiography showed mitral regurgitation. Which of the following is the most common manifestation of this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Arthritis

Explanation:

  • • The clinical presentation suggests acute rheumatic fever (ARF) , which often presents with carditis as one of the major manifestations. In ARF, the most common manifestation is arthritis , which is typically a migratory polyarthritis affecting large joints such as the knees, ankles, elbows, and wrists. This arthritis responds well to nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs).
  • • suggests acute rheumatic fever (ARF)
  • • arthritis
  • • migratory
  • • polyarthritis
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Chorea: This is also a manifestation of ARF but is less common than arthritis.
  • • Option B. Chorea:
  • • Option C. Erythema marginatum: This is a characteristic rash seen in ARF but is less common than arthritis.
  • • Option C. Erythema marginatum:
  • • Option D. Subcutaneous nodules: These are also seen in ARF but are much less common than arthritis.
  • • Option D. Subcutaneous nodules:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In acute rheumatic fever, arthritis is the most common manifestation, typically presenting as migratory polyarthritis that responds well to NSAIDs.

questions.text: A patient is brought to the OPD with complaints of speaking nonsensical and made-up words. However, his speech is easy and fluent. His family claims his speech was fine until a few hours back. Which type of aphasia does the patient most likely have? ( FMGE July 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Sensory aphasia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The patient's symptoms suggest that he is experiencing a type of aphasia where comprehension is impaired, but speech remains fluent. This is characteristic of sensory aphasia (also known as receptive aphasia or fluent aphasia ).
  • • sensory aphasia
  • • receptive aphasia or fluent aphasia
  • • Sensory aphasia (Wernicke's aphasia): Patients with Wernicke's aphasia can speak fluently but their speech often lacks meaning and they have significant difficulty understanding spoken language. They may produce nonsensical and made-up words. This type of aphasia is typically due to a lesion in the posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus (Wernicke's area).
  • • Sensory aphasia (Wernicke's aphasia): Patients with Wernicke's aphasia can speak fluently but their speech often lacks meaning and they have significant difficulty understanding spoken language. They may produce nonsensical and made-up words. This type of aphasia is typically due to a lesion in the posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus (Wernicke's area).
  • • Sensory aphasia (Wernicke's aphasia):
  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • Option B. Motor aphasia (Broca's aphasia): This is a non-fluent aphasia where patients have good comprehension but struggle to produce speech. Speech is typically halting and effortful, and patients may be able to produce only short phrases. This is not consistent with the fluent speech described in the case.
  • • Option B. Motor aphasia (Broca's aphasia):
  • • good comprehension
  • • Option C. Anomic aphasia: Patients with anomic aphasia primarily have difficulty naming objects but otherwise have intact comprehension and fluency . This does not align with the patient’s production of nonsensical words.
  • • Option C. Anomic aphasia:
  • • have intact comprehension and fluency
  • • Option D. Conduction aphasia: This type is characterized by good comprehension and fluent speech , but patients have significant difficulty with repetition. The primary issue in conduction aphasia is the disconnection between comprehension and speech production areas, typically due to damage to the arcuate fasciculus . This does not fully explain the nonsensical speech observed in the patient.
  • • Option D. Conduction aphasia:
  • • good comprehension and fluent speech
  • • arcuate fasciculus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objectives
  • ➤ Sensory aphasia, also known as Wernicke's aphasia, is characterized by fluent but nonsensical speech and impaired comprehension, fitting the described symptoms in this patient.

questions.text: From which structure do the alae of the nose develop? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Lateral nasal process

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The development of the face involves five processes: the frontonasal process, medial nasal processes, lateral nasal processes, maxillary processes, and mandibular processes.
  • • The central part of the face, including the dorsum and tip of the nose, philtrum, and columella, develops from the midline frontonasal process. As the nasal pits develop, they give rise to the medial and lateral nasal processes on each side.
  • • The alae of the nose, which are the lateral flaring parts of the nostrils, develop from the lateral nasal processes.
  • • The maxillary processes give rise to the maxillae, while the mandibular processes form the mandible.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Frontonasal process: Incorrect. The frontonasal process gives rise to the central part of the face, including the dorsum and tip of the nose, philtrum, and columella, but not the alae.
  • • Option
  • • A. Frontonasal process:
  • • Option B. Medial nasal process: Incorrect. The medial nasal processes contribute to the formation of the median part of the nose, but not the alae.
  • • Option B. Medial nasal process:
  • • Option D. Bucconasal membrane: Incorrect. The bucconasal membrane is not one of the five processes involved in facial development and does not give rise to the alae of the nose.
  • • Option D. Bucconasal membrane:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The alae of the nose develop from the lateral nasal processes during facial development.

questions.text: Pencil shaped macroconidia are seen in? ( FMGE July 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Trichophyton

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Pencil-shaped macroconidia are a distinguishing feature of the fungus Trichophyton. Trichophyton is one of the three genera of dermatophytes, which also include Microsporum and Epidermophyton.
  • • Dermatophytes cause infections known as dermatophytosis or ringworm, which affect keratinized tissues such as the skin, hair, and nails.
  • • Dermatophytosis can be classified into three species:
  • • Trichophyton: Involves skin, hair, and nails. The macroconidia are pencil-shaped, and the microconidia are round to piriform (pear-shaped). In the case of Trichophyton, the macroconidia are elongated and resemble pencils. This characteristic helps in differentiating it from other dermatophytes. Microsporum: Primarily involves skin and hair. The macroconidia are spindle-shaped and spiny, while microconidia are usually absent. Epidermophyton: Involves skin and nails. The macroconidia are club-shaped, and microconidia are absent.
  • • Trichophyton: Involves skin, hair, and nails. The macroconidia are pencil-shaped, and the microconidia are round to piriform (pear-shaped). In the case of Trichophyton, the macroconidia are elongated and resemble pencils. This characteristic helps in differentiating it from other dermatophytes.
  • • Trichophyton:
  • • Microsporum: Primarily involves skin and hair. The macroconidia are spindle-shaped and spiny, while microconidia are usually absent.
  • • Microsporum:
  • • Epidermophyton: Involves skin and nails. The macroconidia are club-shaped, and microconidia are absent.
  • • Epidermophyton:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Microsporum: The macroconidia of Microsporum are spindle-shaped and spiny, not pencil-shaped. This genus primarily affects skin and hair.
  • • Option B. Microsporum:
  • • Option C. Epidermophyton: The macroconidia of Epidermophyton are club-shaped, not pencil-shaped. This genus affects skin and nails.
  • • Option C. Epidermophyton:
  • • Option D. Clostridium: This is a genus of bacteria, not fungi, and it does not produce macroconidia. Clostridium species are known for producing spores, not conidia.
  • • Option D. Clostridium:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pencil-shaped macroconidia are characteristic of Trichophyton, a genus of dermatophytes that affects skin, hair, and nails.

questions.text: Which is NOT a hyper-estrogenic condition? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Low BMI

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Hyper-estrogenic conditions are characterized by elevated levels of estrogen. Such conditions can arise due to various factors, including hormonal imbalances, medications, and specific medical conditions.
  • • Low BMI : This is not typically associated with high estrogen levels. In fact, individuals with low BMI may have lower estrogen levels due to decreased adipose tissue, which is a source of estrogen production.
  • • Low BMI
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Tamoxifen use : Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) used primarily in the treatment of breast cancer. It can act as an estrogen agonist in certain tissues, potentially leading to increased estrogenic effects.
  • • Option B. Tamoxifen use
  • • Option C. Nulliparous : Nulliparous women (those who have never given birth) may have higher lifetime exposure to estrogen due to the absence of pregnancy and lactation periods, which would otherwise lower estrogen exposure.
  • • Option C. Nulliparous
  • • Option D. Ovarian cancer : Certain types of ovarian cancer can lead to increased estrogen production, contributing to a hyper-estrogenic state.
  • • Option D. Ovarian cancer

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Low BMI is not associated with hyper-estrogenic conditions.
  • ➤ High estrogen levels are more likely to be seen in conditions such as Tamoxifen use, nulliparity, and certain types of ovarian cancer.
  • ➤ High estrogen is a risk factors for fibroids, endometrial hyperplasia, endometrial carcinoma and endometriosis.

questions.text: Which is the most common intraocular malignancy in adults? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Choroidal metastasis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The most common intraocular malignancy in adults is choroidal metastasis.
  • • Metastatic tumors to the eye, particularly to the choroid, are more common than primary intraocular malignancies. These metastases usually originate from primary cancers in other parts of the body, such as the breast or lung. The choroid is a vascular layer of the eye that provides a conducive environment for metastatic cells to thrive.
  • • The most common primary intraocular malignancy is choroidal melanoma. Choroidal melanoma is the most common primary intraocular cancer in adults, but overall, metastases are more prevalent.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Retinoblastoma : This is the most common primary intraocular malignancy in children , not adults.
  • • Option A. Retinoblastoma
  • • most common
  • • children
  • • Option B. Choroidal melanoma : While this is the most common primary intraocular malignancy in adults , it is less common than metastatic tumors overall.
  • • Option B. Choroidal melanoma
  • • most common primary intraocular malignancy
  • • adults
  • • Option C. Uveal melanoma : This term encompasses melanomas of the choroid, ciliary body, and iris.
  • • Option C. Uveal melanoma

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Identify the maneuver in image below. (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Pringle's maneuver

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The image depicts a surgical procedure known as Pringle's maneuver, which involves inserting a finger from the greater sac to the lesser sac through the epiploic foramen (also known as the foramen of Winslow). The epiploic foramen is the communication between the greater and lesser sacs, and its boundaries are of great importance.
  • • During hepatobiliary surgery, there is a risk of rupturing the vein, artery, and duct (VAD) located along the free margin of the lesser omentum. To prevent leakage from these structures, the surgeon can either clamp them along the free margin or insert a finger behind the lesser omentum and place the thumb above it, compressing the VAD between the finger and thumb. This surgical procedure is known as Pringle's maneuver.
  • • The maneuver involves inserting the finger in front of the stomach (greater sac) and passing it behind the stomach (lesser sac) through the epiploic foramen.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Mattox maneuver: Incorrect. The Mattox maneuver is a surgical technique used to control bleeding from the inferior vena cava or hepatic veins during liver trauma. It involves a thoracoabdominal approach and manual compression of the bleeding site.
  • • Option A. Mattox maneuver:
  • • Option C. Cattell-Braash maneuver: Incorrect. The Cattell-Braash maneuver is a surgical technique used to expose the retroperitoneal structures, such as the aorta, inferior vena cava, and kidneys, by mobilizing the colon and small bowel to the right side of the abdomen.
  • • Option C. Cattell-Braash maneuver:
  • • Option D. Liver hanging maneuver: Incorrect. The liver hanging maneuver is a technique used during liver resection to facilitate the transection of the liver parenchyma. It involves passing a tape or a catheter between the liver and the inferior vena cava to provide traction and guidance during the resection.
  • • Option D. Liver hanging maneuver:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pringle's maneuver is a surgical procedure used to control bleeding during hepatobiliary surgery by compressing the vein, artery, and duct (VAD) along the free margin of the lesser omentum through the epiploic foramen.

questions.text: Identify the type of epidemic.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Common intermittent source epidemic

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The graph shows cases occurring at irregular intervals with gaps between them, indicating that people are exposed intermittently to the source of infection. This pattern is characteristic of a common intermittent source epidemic , where exposures occur sporadically, leading to multiple peaks over time.
  • • common intermittent source epidemic
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Options A. Single exposure, point source epidemic: Characterized by a sudden rise and fall in the number of cases within a single incubation period, showing a single peak.
  • • Options A. Single exposure, point source epidemic:
  • • Options B. Multiple exposure, point source epidemic: Shows multiple peaks due to repeated exposures, but the rise and fall are not as sudden and are marked by secondary waves.
  • • Options B. Multiple exposure, point source epidemic:
  • • Options C. Propagated epidemic: Involves person-to-person transmission, typically showing a slow rise, a plateau, and a slow fall in the number of cases over time.
  • • Options C. Propagated epidemic:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A common intermittent source epidemic is marked by cases appearing at irregular intervals, reflecting intermittent exposures to the source of infection.

questions.text: A 60-year-old bedridden patient develops acute onset dyspnea and chest pain. A CT pulmonary angiography was done. Which screening test will be useful to determine the etiology of this patient's condition? ( FMGE July 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) D-dimer measurement

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In a bedridden patient presenting with acute onset dyspnea and chest pain, one of the primary differential diagnoses is pulmonary embolism (PE). The patient has already undergone CT pulmonary angiography, which is a gold standard for diagnosing PE.
  • • However, for initial screening, D-dimer measurement is very useful:
  • • D-dimer measurement
  • • D-dimer: This test has a high negative predictive value and high sensitivity. It is a good screening test because if the D-dimer level is negative/ normal, it effectively rules out venous thromboembolism (VTE) such as deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and PE. Elevated D-dimer levels indicate that further diagnostic imaging, such as CT pulmonary angiography or compression ultrasound, is needed to confirm the presence of VTE, given its poor specificity.
  • • D-dimer: This test has a high negative predictive value and high sensitivity. It is a good screening test because if the D-dimer level is negative/ normal, it effectively rules out venous thromboembolism (VTE) such as deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and PE.
  • • D-dimer:
  • • Elevated D-dimer levels indicate that further diagnostic imaging, such as CT pulmonary angiography or compression ultrasound, is needed to confirm the presence of VTE, given its poor specificity.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. MR Angiogram: This is an imaging modality that can be used for vascular imaging but is not typically used as a screening test for PE.
  • • Option A. MR Angiogram:
  • • Option B. Echocardiography: This is useful for assessing heart function and diagnosing conditions like heart failure or valvular disease but is not a primary screening test for PE.
  • • Option B. Echocardiography:
  • • Option D. Coagulogram: This test assesses blood coagulation status but is not specifically used for screening for PE.
  • • Option D. Coagulogram:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objectives
  • ➤ D-dimer measurement is an effective screening test for ruling out pulmonary embolism in patients presenting with symptoms suggestive of VTE.

questions.text: Patient died and relatives said he had a tattoo, but it was not visible on autopsy. Which is the best location to check for the evidence of tattoo?(FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Lymph node

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • When a tattoo is not visible on autopsy, it may be due to fading or complete disappearance. In such cases, the best way to check for evidence of the tattoo is to look for the tattoo ink in the nearby lymph nodes.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Spleen: Incorrect because the spleen is not typically involved in draining tattoo ink.
  • • Option A. Spleen:
  • • Option B. Artery: Incorrect as arteries do not play a role in the transport or storage of tattoo ink.
  • • Option B. Artery:
  • • Option D. Liver: Incorrect because the liver is not a primary site for tattoo ink deposition.
  • • Option D. Liver:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When a tattoo is not visible on autopsy, checking the nearby lymph nodes for the presence of tattoo ink is the best approach to find evidence of the tattoo.

questions.text: A 37-year-old female complains of recurrent episodes of discomfort, pain, and a sensation of pressure behind her left eye. She has intermittent proptosis that is reducible. Her symptoms and signs are accentuated when she bends forward. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Orbital varices

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Orbital varices are dilated venous channels in the orbit that can cause intermittent proptosis, which becomes more pronounced with maneuvers that increase venous pressure such as bending forward, straining, or performing a Valsalva maneuver. This intermittent and reducible nature of the proptosis is a key feature distinguishing orbital varices from other conditions.
  • • Additional Information –
  • • Additional Information –
  • • Three types of vascular malformations of the orbit:
  • • Three types of vascular malformations of the orbit:
  • • Type 1 Vascular Malformation (Lymphangioma of the Orbit): This is characterized by no flow and is specifically referred to as lymphangioma of the orbit.
  • • Type 1 Vascular Malformation (Lymphangioma of the Orbit):
  • • Type 2 Vascular Malformation (Orbital Varices): These are identified by having venous flow. Orbital varices typically result in intermittent proptosis, which is particularly exacerbated when the patient is straining, such as during violent coughing, Valsalva maneuvers, or bending forward.
  • • Type 2 Vascular Malformation (Orbital Varices):
  • • Type 3 Vascular Malformation (Arterial or Arteriovenous Flow): This type involves arterial or arteriovenous flow, with orbital arteriovenous (AV) malformations being a classic example.
  • • Type 3 Vascular Malformation (Arterial or Arteriovenous Flow):
  • • Among these, orbital varices (Type 2) are unique, as they cause intermittent proptosis exacerbated by specific physical maneuvers.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Orbital hemangioma: This is the most common benign tumor of the orbit in adults but does not typically cause intermittent proptosis.
  • • Option A. Orbital hemangioma:
  • • Option C. Orbital metastasis: Can cause proptosis but typically presents with persistent proptosis and often with associated signs like eyelid ecchymosis.
  • • Option C. Orbital metastasis:
  • • Option D. Orbital dermoid cyst: Can cause proptosis, but it is usually not intermittent and reducible as described in this case.
  • • Option D. Orbital dermoid cyst:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objectives
  • ➤ Intermittent and reducible proptosis, accentuated by straining or bending forward, is characteristic of orbital varices.

questions.text: Diarrhoea by cholera toxin involves which receptors: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) GM1 ganglioside receptor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cholera toxin, produced by Vibrio cholerae, causes diarrhea by binding to the GM1 ganglioside receptor on the surface of intestinal epithelial cells. The binding of cholera toxin to GM1 facilitates its entry into the cells, where it exerts its toxic effects by activating adenylate cyclase and increasing intracellular cyclic AMP (cAMP). Elevated cAMP levels lead to the secretion of chloride ions and water into the intestinal lumen, resulting in watery diarrhea characteristic of cholera.
  • ➤ Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 212
  • ➤ Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 212

questions.text: At what time during intrauterine life does the talus ossification center appear? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 6 months

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • According to the 42nd edition of Gray's Anatomy, the correct answer is 6 months.
  • • The talus is the uppermost bone of the foot, articulating with the tibia and fibula above and the calcaneus below. The head of the talus articulates with the navicular bone, which is a boat-shaped bone important for the passage of the dorsalis pedis artery. The navicular bone articulates with the three cuneiforms (medial, intermediate, and lateral) and the first three metatarsals. These bones, along with the medial half of the calcaneus, participate in the medial longitudinal arch of the foot.
  • • The 4th and 5th metatarsals, the cuboid bone, and the lateral half of the calcaneus contribute to the lateral longitudinal arch. It is important to note that the phalanges do not participate in the arches of the foot, as demonstrated by the case of New Zealand cricketer Martin Guptill, who had some of his toes amputated without affecting his running and jumping abilities.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Secondary Ossification centers already present when an infant is born includes -
  • ➤ Secondary Ossification centers already present when an infant is born includes -
  • ➤ Distal femur and Proximal tibia - 7 weeks Humerus - 8 weeks Calcaneus - 3-4 th months. Talus – 6 th months Cuboid – 9 th months
  • ➤ Distal femur and Proximal tibia - 7 weeks
  • ➤ Humerus - 8 weeks
  • ➤ Calcaneus - 3-4 th months.
  • ➤ Talus – 6 th months
  • ➤ Talus – 6 th months
  • ➤ Cuboid – 9 th months

questions.text: A person purchased two bottles of alcohol from a local liquor store and subsequently developed symptoms of drowsiness, blurred vision, and ataxia. What is the appropriate antidote for treatment? (Fmge July 2023)
questions.explanation:
